preLesson.title: Before We Begin
content: I'm going to speak much slower than you're used to. This isn't to frustrate you - it's to help you understand how my brain works now.
As you listen, notice your urge to speed things up. That feeling?  That's what families experience. Learning to sit with that discomfort is part of building empathy.

points.title: This Is Immersion, Not Information
points.description: You're about to experience communication from inside dementia, not just learn about it

points.title: The Slowed Speech Is Intentional
points.description: Raman's speech represents the cognitive effort behind each word - this is thinking made audible

points.title: The Pauses Are Real
points.description: These aren't mistakes - they're authentic thinking time that the brain needs

points.title: Your Role
points.description: Don't just listen to learn - listen to understand what it feels like

speechExplanation.title: About Raman's Speech

lessons.title: Meet Raman
lessons.content: Hello. I'm Raman. I have dementia. I want to help you understand me.

insights.text: First impressions matter more now - your calm energy helps me feel safe
I'm still the same person inside - dementia doesn't erase who I am
Building trust takes time, but your patience creates the foundation
When you rush, I feel anxious. When you're calm, I can be myself

lessons.title: Why I Need Time
lessons.content: When you talk to me. I need time. My brain works slower now. Please wait for me.

insights.text: My brain processes like a computer with limited memory - everything takes longer
10 seconds feels like forever to you, but it's normal thinking time for me
Finishing my sentences interrupts my thought process and makes me start over
Your patience gives me the gift of completing my own thoughts

lessons.title: One Thing at a Time
lessons.content: Too many instructions. I get confused. Tell me one thing. Then wait.

insights.text: Multiple tasks create a mental traffic jam - I can't process them all at once
'Put on your shoes' works better than 'Get dressed and ready to go'
One clear instruction helps me succeed instead of feeling overwhelmed
Breaking tasks into steps isn't treating me like a child - it's helping me win

lessons.title: Don't Interrupt My Thoughts
lessons.content: Sometimes I stop talking. but I'm still thinking. Please don't jump in. Let me finish.

insights.text: When you interrupt, I lose my train of thought and have to start searching again
Silence doesn't mean I'm stuck - it means I'm working hard to find the right words
Watch my face during pauses - I'm often still communicating through expressions
Letting me finish my thoughts builds my confidence and preserves my dignity

lessons.title: How Words Make Me Feel
lessons.content: When you say 'Don't forget your medicine'. I feel bad. Instead say, 'Here's your medicine'. I feel good. Same message. Different feeling.

insights.text: 'Don't forget' reminds me of my failures. 'Here's your...' focuses on the solution
My emotions work fine - harsh words hurt just as much as they always did
Instead of 'You asked that already,' try 'Great question, let me tell you again'
How you speak to me shapes how I feel about myself throughout the day

lesson1.title: Meet Raman
lesson1.initialQuestion: Thank you for listening to me. I'm curious... Did your body tense up when I said 'dementia'? Notice what happened in your shoulders or jaw.
lesson1.context: This is lesson 1 about meeting Raman and first impressions.
lesson1.learningGoal: Help user recognize their physical reactions to dementia disclosure

lesson2.title: Why I Need Time
lesson2.initialQuestion: I noticed those pauses in my speech. What was harder for you - the slow speech or the long silences? What emotions came up?
lesson2.context: This is lesson 2 about needing time and patience.
lesson2.learningGoal: Help user identify their emotional responses to communication delays

lesson3.title: One Thing at a Time
lesson3.initialQuestion: When I talked about getting confused with too many instructions, how many times did you want to jump in and 'help' or organize things for me?
lesson3.context: This is lesson 3 about cognitive overload and simple instructions.
lesson3.learningGoal: Help user recognize their impulse to intervene or fix

lesson4.title: Don't Interrupt My Thoughts
lesson4.initialQuestion: Now imagine feeling this rushed in every conversation, every day. How would that change you? What would it feel like to have your thinking interrupted constantly?
lesson4.context: This is lesson 4 about not interrupting thought processes.
lesson4.learningGoal: Help user develop empathy through perspective-taking

lesson5.title: How Words Make Me Feel
lesson5.initialQuestion: Think of someone in your life - maybe a parent, spouse, or friend. What's one specific thing you'll do differently after meeting me?
lesson5.context: This is lesson 5 about the emotional impact of word choices.
lesson5.learningGoal: Help user commit to specific behavioral changes

responses: That's a very honest reaction. Many people feel tension when they first hear the word 'dementia.' The fact that you noticed your body's response shows you're really paying attention.
My wife had a similar reaction when I was first diagnosed. Your awareness of these physical responses will help you connect better with people like me.
In my business days, I learned that first impressions happen in seconds. Your body knew something important was happening before your mind caught up.
The silences are often harder than the slow speech, aren't they? My daughter told me the same thing - waiting feels more difficult than listening slowly.
When I was running my company, I used to hate waiting too. Now I understand that patience isn't just politeness - it's kindness.
Those emotions you felt are completely normal. Every family member I've talked to experiences some frustration with the pace.
That urge to help and organize is so natural - my son does the same thing. But sometimes the best help is just letting me figure it out my way.
In business, I was always the one trying to make things more efficient. Now I'm learning that efficiency isn't always what matters most.
It's interesting how we want to fix things, isn't it? My wife has learned that sometimes I don't need fixing - just understanding.
That feeling of being rushed constantly - it's exhausting. Imagine if every conversation in your day felt like you were being hurried along.
My daughters are getting better at this, but it took time. When someone waits for my thoughts, I feel respected instead of broken.
In my work years, I interrupted people all the time. Now I understand how it feels to have your thinking process cut off mid-stream.
That's wonderful that you're thinking of someone specific. Small changes in how we phrase things can make such a big difference in how loved someone feels.
My wife started doing exactly that - turning reminders into caring gestures. Instead of 'Don't forget your jacket,' she says 'I brought your jacket.' Same action, completely different feeling.
The fact that you're ready to make a specific change tells me this conversation has been meaningful. That person in your life is lucky to have you thinking about them this way.

fallbackResponses.error: I'm having trouble responding right now. Your thoughts are important to me.
fallbackResponses.inappropriate: I appreciate you sharing, but let's keep our conversation focused on communication and connection.
fallbackResponses.technical: Something went wrong with our chat. Would you like to continue to the next lesson?
fallbackResponses.generic: Thank you for sharing that with me. Your awareness is really important.

transitions.exitReflection: Thank you for sharing your thoughts with me.
transitions.nextLesson: Let's continue to the next lesson.
transitions.courseComplete: You've completed all lessons with me. Thank you for this journey.

cards.prompt: Notice your first reaction when I said 'dementia' - what happened in your body?
Did you lean forward or pull back? Your body language shows how you're feeling.
I'm still the same person inside. Did that surprise you?
How comfortable are you with silence? Notice any urge to fill the pause.
Did you feel impatient? Frustrated? Those feelings are completely normal.
What would patience feel like if you were the one needing time?
How many tasks do you usually give people at once? Count them.
Did you want to 'help' me organize my thoughts better?
Breaking things down isn't treating me like a child - it's helping me succeed.
How many times did you want to finish my sentence?
Imagine losing your train of thought every time someone interrupts.
Now imagine this happening in EVERY conversation, EVERY day.
Think of someone you love. How do you usually remind them of things?
Same message, different feeling. What's the difference?
What's ONE specific thing you'll do differently after meeting me?
